qas.question: What is a major implication of the Erie doctrine?

answers.text: federal courts cannot dictate the content of state law when there is no federal issue

qas.question: What are states not bound by?
What states that deference is one way only?
What does it mean when Erie states that deference is one way only?

answers.text: state courts are not bound by federal interpretations of state law

qas.question: The Erie doctrine allows federal courts to intercede even when there is no what?
What doctrine states that state courts are bound by federal interpretations?

plausible_answers.text: the relevant state law is irrational or just bad public policy

qas.question: When can federal trial courts ignore state law?
What must federal trial courts apply when the state law is not pursuant?

plausible_answers.text: dictate the content of state law

qas.question: The Erie doctrine states that federal courts can do what?
